macro.abstract: The macro tests whether a is unused.
macro.para: If __VA_ARGS__ contains only a single argument, this macro expands to 1. Otherwise, it expands to 0.

usage.param: The argument from which a is to be extracted.

macro.para: If __VA_ARGS__ contains more than a single argument, this macro expands to the arguments following the first. Otherwise, it expands to nothing.

macro.abstract: The macro extracts the non-optional argument to which a may be attached.

usage.param: The argument from which the non-optional argument is to be extracted.

macro.para: This macro expands to the first argument of __VA_ARGS__.

macro.abstract: The argument is used to preserve a (or lack thereof) in subsequent invocations.

usage.param: The argument whose is to be packed.

macro.para:
If __VA_ARGS__ contains more than a single argument, this macro expands to an expression of the form...
(, args)
...where args is a placeholder for all the arguments in __VA_ARGS__ except the first. Otherwise, this macro expands to nullary parentheses.
The result of this macro is subsequently unpacked by in a context to propogate a .

macro.abstract: The macro unpacks an argument previously packed with .

usage.param: The parenthetic expression to be unpacked.

macro.para:
In C99, this macro expands to the contents of the parenthetic expression pack (which may or may not contain a leading comma).
#define A () #define B (, data)
(A) // (B) // , data
In C and C++, pack must be a unary parenthetic expression, and this macro expands to the element contained by the unary parenthetic expression plus a leading comma.
#define A (data) (A) // , data
This macro is used to propogate in .
